thread.title: England's Heroics Prove To Be All In Vain
thread.title_full: England's Heroics Prove To Be All In Vain

title: England's Heroics Prove To Be All In Vain
text:
England's Heroics Prove To Be All In Vain 13:36, UK, Monday 26 October 2015 Share by email Adil Rashid's gutsy, maiden Test fifty proved in vain as Pakistan took an unassailable 1-0 series lead with a 178-run victory over England in Dubai. 
Rashid (61) valiantly thwarted the home side for 172 balls, but could not quite marshal Alastair Cook's side to a draw despite stands of 60 with Stuart Broad (30) and 55 with Mark Wood (29 off 95) as the tourists were bowled out for 312 with a minimum of 6.3 overs left. 
England's hopes of saving the match seemed all but lost when Rashid, playing only his second Test, came to the wicket with the tourists - set an improbable 491 to win - struggling on 178-6 with 63 overs remaining. 
But the Yorkshire all-rounder showed pinpoint judgement to leave the ball well on a turning pitch - his stand with Wood the longest ninth-wicket partnership in the fourth innings of a Test match in terms of ball faced (29.2 overs). 
With men camped around the bat, Asad Shafiq dropped James Anderson at short leg off Zulfiqar Babar with just 7.5 overs left. 
But England's resistance came to an end when Rashid was caught at cover on the drive off the spin of Yasir Shah with the light fading fast. 
Pakistan, currently fourth in the ICC world rankings behind England, will climb to number two above Australia if they complete a 2-0 series victory in the third Test, which begins in Sharjah on Sunday. 
They are yet to lose a Test series "at home" since they were forced to play their matches in the United Arab Emirates in 2010, while the defeat means that England have now lost eight and won only two of their last 29 away Tests against Pakistan. 
After their first Test victory charge was halted by bad light in Abu Dhabi, Cook's side paid the price for losing seven wickets for 36 runs on day three - a collapse that cost them a first-innings deficit of 136. 
The tourists, who were 130-3 overnight, needed a solid first session to have a chance of batting through the day but lost three wickets before lunch. 
Joe Root, 59 not out overnight, knocked off the two runs he needed to become the second-youngest England batsman after Alastair Cook to score 3,000 Test runs, aged 24 years and 200 days. 
But he added just 10 runs more before failing to get to the pitch of a Zulfiqar delivery and edging to slip where Younus Khan snaffled the low chance, falling for 71 off 171 balls. 
Jonny Bairstow (22) - dropped by Shan Masood on 10 - was the next to go in the second over after drinks when he failed to spot Yasir's googly and was bowled through the gate trying to work to leg. 
Younus claimed his fourth catch of the innings when Jos Buttler (seven) had no option but to play at a sharply-turning leg-break from Yasir, the veteran grabbing the chance. 
England's position looked perilous at 183-6 at lunch and took another turn for the worse in the third over after the break when Ben Stokes pushed at a delivery from Imran Khan and snicked to Misbah-ul-Haq at second slip. 
Pakistan's progress was briefly held up by an obdurate eighth-wicket stand of 60 between Broad and Rashid, who pulled Yasir emphatically for four to bring up the pair's 50-run partnership off 77 balls. 
Broad (30 off 42) withstood the expected short ball barrage only to nearly be undone on 23 by a full Wahab Riaz delivery that he chipped between two short legs. The reprieve was short-lived as Wahab produced a superb in-swinging yorker to bowl him seven runs later in the 104th over. 
Wood gave the innings some welcome thrust, crunching 14 runs off four balls off Wahab, and Rashid received a life on 42 when Hafeez couldn't cling onto a tough chance in the gully off Yasir. 
Rashid posted his fifty off 110 balls with a scampered single to mid-on - Wood perilously close to being run out - and the pair's fifty stand came up off 165 deliveries. 
Just when Pakistan's hopes appeared to be rapidly declining with 11.1 overs left, Wood snicked Zulfiqar to Mohammad Hafeez at slip and Rashid's heroics weren't quite enough, his downfall sparking jubilant Pakistan celebrations. Promoted Stories
